children.name: opinion
children.definition: your ideas or beliefs about a particular subject
examples: COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'according to my opinion'. Sayin my opinion.
Do not say 'say your opinion'. Saygive your opinionorexpress your opinion.

children.name: have/hold an opinion
examples: Everyone seemed to have a different opinion.|He holds strong opinions on these issues.

children.name: ask sb
children.definition: for
examples: their opinion(alsoask for sb’s opinion)We asked people for their opinions about the Olympics.|Nobody asked my opinion.|It’s a good idea to ask people for their opinions and suggestions.

children.name: give/express an opinion
children.definition: say what your opinion is
examples: He gave his opinion only when asked.

children.name: voice/state an opinionwritten
children.definition: give your opinion, especially in a formal situation
examples: She has every right to voice her opinion.

children.name: form an opinion
children.definition: gradually decide what your opinion is
examples: Olson had not yet formed an opinion as to Mark’s reliability.

children.name: the general opinion
children.definition: the opinion that most people have about something
examples: The general opinion seems to be that the government has made a mess of the war.

children.name: popular/public opinion
children.definition: what ordinary people think about something
examples: How much do newspapers influence popular opinion?

children.name: sb’s personal opinion
examples: My personal opinion is that his first film was better.

children.name: strong opinions
examples: People have strong opinions about this subject.

children.name: have a difference of opinion
children.definition: two people disagree
examples: He and Luke had a difference of opinion.

children.name: sth is a matter of opinion
children.definition: used to say that you disagree, or that people disagree about something
examples: "He’s a very nice man." "That’s a matter of opinion," thought Sam.

children.name: contrary to popular opinion
children.definition: in spite of what most people think
examples: Contrary to popular opinion, many cats dislike milk.

children.name: in my humble opinion
children.definition: used when giving your opinion, especially when you want to emphasize what you are about to say
examples: In my humble opinion, he is the greatest sportsman Britain has produced.

children.name: keep your opinions to yourself
children.definition: not say what you really think
examples: As the youngest person there, I knew enough to keep my opinions to myself.

children.name: opinion is divided as to/on/over something
children.definition: people have different opinions about it
examples: Opinion was divided as to whether the program will work.

children.name: everyone is entitled to their opinion
children.definition: used especially when politely disagreeing with what someone says
examples: Of course everyone is entitled to their opinion, but I can't accept what he is saying.

children.name: opinion of
examples: What’s your opinion of Cathy?

children.name: opinion on
examples: He asked his wife’s opinion on every important decision.

children.name: opinion about
examples: The two women had very different opinions about drugs.

children.name: in my opinion(= used when giving your opinion )
examples: In my opinion, the law should be changed.

children.name: sb’s opinion
examples: Do you really want my opinion?

children.name: have a high/low opinion of sb/sththink sth sb is good or bad: có ý kiến về cái gì/ai đó
examples: Politicians generally have a low opinion of the press.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayI think ...rather thanmy opinion is ...orin my opinion .... In questions, people usually askwhat do you think?rather thanwhat is your opinion?:
What do you thinkof Cathy?

children.name: be of the opinion thathave a particular opinionformal
examples: The coroner was of the opinion that the man had been dead for only 24 hours.
sb is entitled to their opinionsay this when you disagree with sb else’s opinion:
He’s entitled to his opinion, of course, but it does not give him the right to be offensive.

children.name: what you think
children.definition: of/about sth especially spoken your opinion about something, especially whether you think it is good or bad:
examples: ▪ What do you think of her new CD?
▪ Tell me what you think about the design.
▪ No one ever really stops and asks kids what they think about things.
▪ Well, I know what I think, but you might not agree.

children.name: view
children.definition: your opinion about something, especially about a serious or important subject: quan điểm
examples: view on/about
What’s your view on the subject?
view that
Their view is that competition is good for business.
in my view
In my view, the country needs a change of government.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayI think ...rather thanIn my view ..., andWhat do you think?rather thanWhat is your view?:
What do you thinkabout her new boyfriend?
extremea politician who has extreme views on immigration
traditionaltraditional views about women
right-wing/left-wingthe students’ extreme left-wing views

children.name: have/hold a view
children.definition: have an opinion
examples: He has very left-wing views.

children.name: take the view that ...
children.definition: have a particular view
examples: The Government took the view that the law did not need to be changed.

children.name: express a view
children.definition: say what you think about something
examples: This is a chance for you to express your views.

children.name: give your view
children.definition: say what you think
examples: He did not hesitate to give his own views on the subject.

children.name: share a view
children.definition: agree with it
examples: This view is not shared by his colleagues.

children.name: support a view
children.definition: believe or help to prove that it is right
examples: There are many people who would support his views.

children.name: hear a view
children.definition: alsolisten to a view
examples: a chance to hear people’s views on a range of different subjects

children.name: tell sb your view
children.definition: alsolet somebody have your view
examples: We want you to tell us your views.

children.name: sb’s view changes
examples: Your view about these things changes as you get older.

children.name: political views
examples: His political views have not changed.

children.name: sb’s personal view
examples: My own personal view is that they’re being optimistic.

children.name: widely-held view
examples: There is a widely-held view that young people eat too much junk food.

children.name: the general view
children.definition: what most people think
examples: The general view was that he had done well.

children.name: strong views
examples: She has strong views on education.

children.name: strongly held/deeply held views
children.definition: strong views that someone is unwilling to change
examples: He is known for his strongly held views on modern art.

children.name: different views
examples: Different people have different views about this subject.

children.name: conflicting/opposing views
children.definition: completely different
examples: There are conflicting views about the best way to teach reading.

children.name: moderate
examples: His views have recently become more moderate.

children.name: outrageous
examples: The chairman said that Mr McNeil's views were outrageous.

children.name: old-fashioned
examples: Some of his views now sound very old-fashioned.

children.name: popular/unpopular
examples: This view has become increasingly popular in society.|It’s now a rather unpopular view.

children.name: be of the same view
children.definition: agree
examples: They were all of the same view.

children.name: be of differing/different views
children.definition: disagree
examples: They get on well, though they are of differing views on politics.

children.name: an exchange of views
children.definition: when people say what they think, especially when they disagree
examples: There was a frank exchange of views at the meeting.

children.name: attitude
children.definition: the opinions and feelings that you usually have about something, especially when this is shown in your behaviour: thái độ
examples: As soon as they found out I was a doctor, their whole attitude changed.
attitude to/towards
The people have a very positive attitude to life.
good/bada lazy student with a bad attitude
political attitudesa survey of people’s political attitudes

children.name: positive/negative
examples: A positive attitude is essential if you want to be successful.|Many teenagers have a very negative attitude towards cooking.

children.name: relaxed
examples: On Bali, there is a healthier, more relaxed attitude to life.

children.name: favourable
children.definition: having a good opinion of something or someone
examples: Older people tend to have a favourable attitude to the police.

children.name: critical
children.definition: showing you disagree with or disapprove of someone or something
examples: People’s attitude towards US foreign policy has become increasingly critical.

children.name: ambivalent
children.definition: not sure if you approve of something
examples: The public have a rather ambivalent attitude towards science.

children.name: cavalier
children.definition: very careless, especially about something serious or important
examples: his cavalier attitude to the truth

children.name: patronizing/condescending
children.definition: showing that you think you are more important or intelligent than someone
examples: complaints about patronising attitudes towards women

children.name: aggressive/hostile
children.definition: showing anger
examples: Their attitude suddenly became more aggressive.

children.name: public attitudes/people’s attitudes
examples: Public attitudes have changed.

children.name: mental attitude
examples: There is a strong connection between health and mental attitude.

children.name: sb’s whole attitude
examples: His whole attitude seemed different.

children.name: the general attitude
examples: His general attitude to our situation was unsympathetic.

children.name: have/take/adopt an attitude
examples: Not everyone takes a positive attitude towards modern art.

children.name: sb’s attitude changes
examples: As you get older, your attitude changes.

children.name: an attitude exists
examples: This attitude no longer exists in the church.

children.name: sb’s attitude hardens
children.definition: they feel less sympathy and they want to be stricter or firmer
examples: People’s attitudes towards sex offenders have hardened.

children.name: an attitude of mindBritish English
children.definition: a way of thinking
examples: Being young is simply an attitude of mind.

children.name: sb has an attitude problem
children.definition: sb is not helpful or pleasant to be with
examples: Some of the male students have a real attitude problem.

children.name: thoughts
children.definition: your opinion about sth, especially about what should be done about it, after you have thought about it carefully: suy nghĩ, ý kiến

children.name: thoughts about/on
examples: ▪ Does anyone have any thoughts or suggestions about how we should spend the money?
▪ I was anxious to hear his thoughts on the scenes I had written.

children.name: have thoughts
examples: ▪ Please get back to me with any thoughts you might have on this.

children.name: idea
children.definition: what you think about sth, especially about the best way to deal with sth: ý tưởng
examples: I’m not sure his ideas will be very popular with the voters.

children.name: ideas about/on
examples: His ideas about marriage and divorce were very old-fashioned.
I’d like your ideas on how we can improve our working relationship.
She had some rather unusual ideas about raising children.

children.name: idea that
examples: Leach puts forward the ideathatit is impossible to spoil a child.

children.name: where did you get that idea?(= used to say that what sb thinks is completely wrong)
examples: No, I’m not seeing Jane. Where did you get that idea?

children.name: what a particular group think about sth
opinion
children.definition: anopinionshared by a group of people, especially a particular profession or group of people who can influence what is decided: quan điểm

children.name: government/professional/medical etc opinion
examples: Medical opinion is divided as to the effectiveness of the new drug.

children.name: world opiniondư luận thế giới
examples: Their refusal to obey UN regulations had a major effect on world opinion.

children.name: thinking
children.definition: an opinion that a group has at a particular time, especially about the best way of doing sth: suy nghĩ, quan điểm
examples: His statements closely reflect government thinking.
There has been a change in thinking in terms of the influence of diet on the disease.
thinking on
The report goes

children.name: body of opinion
children.definition: an opinion shared by a large group of people, that is considered to be important or that should be listened to: quan điểm
examples: A significant body of opinion is strongly opposed to the new proposals.
There is a growing body of opinion that says we should put the environment first.

children.name: school of thought
children.definition: an opinion that one group of people have about a subject, especially when this is different from that of another group: trường phái
examples: There is one school of thought that says that coffee is addictive and is therefore a bad thing.
There are two schools of thought on this.

children.name: the way you generally think about sth
way of thinking U
children.definition: way of thinking the attitude of a person or group, especially about what other people should or should not do: cách nghĩ
examples: You’ll come to understand my way of thinking when you’re my age and you have your own children to worry about.
I was glad to be with people who shared my way of thinking.

children.name: outlook
children.definition: your general attitude to life and the world: cách nhìn(cuộc sống)
examples: After a good vacation, you’ll have a completely different outlook.
The farmers were narrowly provincial in their outlook.

children.name: a positive/optimistic outlook
examples: Despite her health problems, she has a positive outlook.

children.name: a negative/pessimistic outlook
examples: This pessimistic outlook on their lives leads to depression.

children.name: a wider/broader outlook
examples: Education should give students a wider outlook on life.

children.name: a new/fresh outlook
children.definition: new and interesting
examples: I saw Helen last week and she seemed to have a fresh outlook on life.

children.name: somebody's mental outlook
children.definition: how you feel about the things in your life
examples: Exercise can help improve your mental outlook.

children.name: somebody's religious outlook
examples: The Puritans' religious outlook affected every aspect of their lives.

children.name: somebody's moral/ethical outlook
children.definition: beliefs about what is right and wrong
examples: Their ethical and moral outlook concerning terrorism is the complete opposite of mine.

children.name: have an outlook
examples: He has quite a conventional outlook.

children.name: give somebody an outlook
examples: June's new job gave her a fresh outlook.

children.name: change somebody's outlook
examples: None of my arguments could change his outlook or behavior.

children.name: outlook on
examples: His outlook on life is largely a result of his strict education.
He has a fairly positive outlookonlife.
He’s got a goodoutlook on life.
Exercise will improve your looks and your outlook.

children.name: world view
children.definition: the attitude that a person, group or nation has towards life or the world: thế giới quan
examples: The traditional Indian world view is based on certain definite concepts.

children.name: the Communist world view
examples: He believes the change in the world view has occurred because of the new developments in communications.

children.name: mindset
children.definition: the way a particular person or group tends to think, especially when this is difficult to change: lối tư duy
examples: The residents of this city have an insular mindset, so strangers are not always made welcome.
The mindset of that generation was definitely more obedient than today’s.
There does seem to have been a slight shift in the government’s mindset in the light of recent events.

children.name: what most people think about sth
public opinion
children.definition: / popular opinion what most of the people of a country think about a particular subject, idea, or problem: dư luận công chúng
examples: Responding to public opinion, the government introduced new controls on guns.
Popular opinion is quite easily swayed by the media.
Public opinion should not influence every policy decision.
The shooting of an intruder by a farmer has sharply divided popular opinion.

children.name: majority view U
children.definition: majority viewwhat most of the people in a group or a society think about sth: quan điểm đa số, ý kiến đa số
examples: The majority view seems to be that we need more police officers on local streets.
The mayor was quick to point out that the racist group did not represent a majority view in the community.

children.name: the official opinion of a person or group
position
children.definition: what a government, political party, or a person has decided to be their official or public opinion: lập trường
examples: ▪ It’s important that the Socialists clarify their position before the conference.
I hope you’llreconsideryourposition.

children.name: position on
examples: ▪ We have made our position on disarmament perfectly clear.
What’s the party’s position on tax reform?

children.name: take a position
examples: ▪ She takes the position that all asylum seekers should be made welcome.
The principaltooktheposition thatthe students didn’t need music classes.

children.name: line
children.definition: the publicly stated opinion of a political party, government etc, which all their members are supposed to agree with: luồng ý kiến, đường lối

children.name: party/government/official etc line
examples: The whip’s job is to persuade members of his party to support the party line on issues that come before Congress.

children.name: line on
examples: What’s his line on abortion?

children.name: take a line on sth
examples: There was pressure for the President to take a tough line on welfare issues.

children.name: stance
children.definition: the publicly stated opinion of a person, group, newspaper etc towards sth, especially a political matter: quan điểm, lập trường
examples: The political stance of the paper means it is unlikely to report the affair in a balanced way.
The official stance is that the lottery money should be used for the arts and education.

children.name: stance on
examples: His tough stance on crime appeals to voters.
The doctor's stanceonthe issue of abortion is well known.

children.name: take a stance on sth
examples: The council has taken a pro-growth, pro-business stance on development issues.

children.name: where sb stands
children.definition: the publicly stated opinion of a person or group, especially when previously this may not have been clear: quan điểm, lập trường
examples: Voters need to know where each candidate stands.

children.name: where sb stands on
examples: Where do the Democrats stand on the issue of sanctions?

children.name: an opinion that is influenced by the situation you are in
point of view
children.definition: quan điểm, cách nhìn
examples: 1a particular way of thinking about or judging a situation :

children.name: from a practical point of view
examples: Saving energy in your home is fairly easy from a practical point of view.

children.name: from an economic/financial/business point of view
examples: From a financial point of view, the concert was a disaster.

children.name: from a scientific/technical point of view
examples: This book was the first to study language from a scientific point of view.

children.name: from a legal point of view
examples: It's a fascinating case, from a legal point of view.

children.name: from a political point of view
examples: From the political point of view, it was important that the country showed it was adhering to the treaty.

children.name: from a security point of view
examples: The system is seriously flawed from a security point of view.

children.name: scientific/technical/business etc point of view
examples: Froman economicpoint of view, the new development will benefit the town greatly.
2sb’s own personal opinion or attitude about sth :
I respect your point of view, but I’m not sure I agree with you.

children.name: see to sb’s point of view(= understand)
examples: You have to be willing toseeother people's points of view.

children.name: from sb’s point of view
examples: From my point of view, there is no way they can win.
I appreciate thatfromyour point of view it's an unwelcome development.

children.name: listen to sb’s point of view
examples: She’s always ready to listen to other people’s point of view.

children.name: viewpoint
children.definition: a particular way of thinking about a problem or subject: điểm nhìn
examples: We need to seriously consider all the different viewpoints on the issue.
viewpoint on
the Church’s viewpoint on divorce
political/scientific/feminist etc viewpoint
From an ecological viewpoint, the motorway has been a disaster.
from sb’s viewpoint/from the viewpoint of sb/sth
Try and think of it from the child’s viewpoint.
The islands were important from the viewpoint of American security.
The TV series examines childhood from the viewpoints of twelve different families.
from a historical/feminist/democratic etc viewpoint
The book looks at the Royal family from a sociological and historical viewpoint.

children.name: standpoint
children.definition: a particular way of thinking about sth, especially of someone who is involved in a situation or who has to make a professional judgment about it: điểm nhìn
examples: a discussion of marriagefrom the standpoint ofwomen
from sb’s standpoint
From the teacher’s standpoint, the new tests just mean more work.
from a theoretical/political/economic etc standpoint
Let’s look at the questions from an economic standpoint.
His books have sold in the millions, but from a literary standpoint they aren’t really very good

children.name: angle
children.definition: one of a number of ways of thinking about sth that should be considered when dealing with a particular problem or subject: gốc độ, gốc nhìn, khía cạnh
examples: Look atevery angleof the situation.
The press was looking for anew/freshangleonthe situation.
Advertisers need to find the right angle to make their product appeal to consumers.
The article gives the reader a fresh angle on pop culture
from an angle
We’re approaching the issuefrommanydifferent angles.
Try looking at the problemfromanother angle/frommy angle.
look at/view/examine etc sth from an angle
Thompson says his committee has looked at the problem from every possible angle.
angle on
They wanted an ordinary worker’s angle on the new system.
angle to
There’s another angle to this question.

children.name: perspective
children.definition: a way of thinking about something, especially one which is influenced by the type of person you are or by your experiences: quan điểm

children.name: a new/different perspective
examples: I like the programme because it gives you a different perspective on world news.

children.name: a fresh perspective
children.definition: new and interesting or useful
examples: The venture will benefit from their fresh perspective.

children.name: a wider/broader perspective
examples: Searching through a variety of sources will give them a wider perspective on their subject.

children.name: a historical perspective
examples: It is important to have a historical perspective when considering these changes.

children.name: a global/international perspective
examples: A global perspective allows firms to spot opportunities and reduce supply costs.

children.name: a feminist perspective
examples: If you look at this from a feminist perspective, things are, in fact, not equal.

children.name: a female perspective
examples: Carson's lyrics are definitely written from the human experience, but from a female perspective.

children.name: a
examples: Marxist perspectiveFrom a Marxist perspective, crime is largely the product of capitalism.

children.name: a
examples: Christian perspectiveWe approach the problem from a Christian perspective.

children.name: a business perspective
examples: I think it was a good thing to do, from a business perspective.

children.name: the
examples: American/Russian/French etc perspectiveFrom the French perspective, therefore, 1934 marks a major turning point.

children.name: have a perspective
examples: Everyone seems to have a different perspective on the issue.

children.name: see/view something from a perspective
examples: A child can only see see the world from his or her own perspective.

children.name: give
children.definition: sb
examples: a perspectiveA break might give her a better perspective on things.

children.name: provide a perspective
examples: Their research is concerned with providing an alternative perspective on our past.

children.name: offer a perspective
examples: Bamford offers a fresh perspective on this ongoing historical debate.

children.name: get a perspective
examples: When you get to my age, you get a different perspective on life.

children.name: put a perspective on something
examples: This new evidence put a whole new perspective on the case.

children.name: perspective on
examples: His father’s death gave him a whole new perspective on life.

children.name: from sb’s perspective
examples: Feminists say that the book was written from a male perspective.
The novel is written from a child’s perspective.

children.name: from a feminist/Christian/global etc perspective
examples: We have to look at everything from an international perspective.

children.name: what sb think about sth, especially one based on emotion
feeling
children.definition: sb’s feelings are their thoughts, emotions, and attitudes: cảm nhận, cả nghĩ
examples: He makes decisions without ever taking my feelings into account.
m feeling is that
My personal feeling is that not enough has been done.
My feeling is that we had better act quickly or it will be too late.
feelings on/about
Kids’ feelings about everything from reading to exercise are influenced by their parents
She hasstrong feelingson the issue of abortion.
a survey on people’s feelings about the candidates
strong feelings
She has very strong feelings about this election.
Hisgut feeling(= opinion based on emotion )was that Burns was probably guilty.
I had thisfunny feeling(= not easily explained )that something was wrong.

children.name: sentiment
children.definition: especially writtenan opinion, especially one that is based on emotion: cảm nhận
examples: The speeches were full of nationalist sentiments.
Most people were outraged by the bombing, and their letters of sympathy reflected this sentiment.
Similar sentiments were expressed by many politicians.
public/popular sentimentwhat most people think: suy nghĩ của dư luận/ phô biến
Several meetings were held to determine what public sentiment was on the issue.
He was more in touch with public sentiment than many of his critics.
anti-American/anti-nationalistic/anti-religious etc sentiments
the anti-immigrant sentiments expressed by some Americans
‘After all, it’s her decision.’ ‘My sentiments exactly(= I agree ).’
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayfeelingrather thansentiment:
They all expressed similarfeelings.

children.name: view
children.definition: a way of thinking about or understanding something
examples: view of
Mum’s view of the situation was different to mine.
optimistic/pessimistic/balanced etc view
a realistic view of human nature
traditional views of religion
You need tohaveaclear view(= a definite idea )of the kind of book you want to write.
take a dim/poor view of something(= disapprove )
She took a pretty dim view of his behaviour.
